H0.text: Chemical is the type of change demonstrated when a teacher pours sulfuric acid on granulated sugar in a beaker, causing the sugar to turn yellow and then black, smoke to rise, and a strong smell to be released.

H1.text: Physical is the type of change demonstrated when a teacher pours sulfuric acid on granulated sugar in a beaker, causing the sugar to turn yellow and then black, smoke to rise, and a strong smell to be released.

H2.text: Magnetic is the type of change demonstrated when a teacher pours sulfuric acid onto granulated sugar in a beaker, causing the sugar to turn yellow then black, smoke to rise, and a strong smell to be released.

H3.text: Electric is the type of change demonstrated when a teacher pours sulfuric acid onto granulated sugar in a beaker, causing the sugar to turn yellow and then black, smoke to rise, and a strong smell to be released.

A4.text: Chemical reactions are usually characterized by a chemical change, and they yield one or more products, which usually have properties different from the reactants.
